awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2018, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. Global change has produced key challenges to ecosystems today. These are challenges that the fossil record, which preserves biological responses to major disturbances over thousands to millions of years, is well-equipped to explain. This project focuses on two disturbances that impacted ecosystems approximately 10,000 years ago: the end of the last Ice Age, and the extinction of very large mammals (megafauna). These two events gave rise to abnormal present-day communities in which the largest predators tend to be medium- to small-sized mesocarnivores, like coyotes and bobcats. In the face of continuing global change and the removal of large carnivores like grey wolves, mesocarnivores before and after the dual disturbances present a natural laboratory for tracking how mammal communities respond to large-scale ecological and environmental perturbation. Set at the La Brea Tar Pits in Los Angeles, California, this project embodies a double meaning for "community paleoecology": involving the diverse human communities of modern LA in studying the diverse carnivore communities of prehistoric LA. Using the paleontology of charismatic mesocarnivores as a "gateway science" by which to introduce the scientific method, the Fellow will: (1) train student interns from community colleges and UC Merced to identify and describe fossil species; and (2) crowdsource collection of paleoecological data by museum visitors, adding to a dynamic museum experience.

To investigate living mesocarnivores in the aftermath of climatic change and megafaunal extinction, the Fellow is integrating radiocarbon dating, systematic taxonomy, geometric morphometrics, and stable isotope analysis of mesocarnivores and their prey from California ecosystems preserved over the past 50,000 years. The Fellow aims to: (1) build a robust temporal framework, ranging from pre-Last Glacial Maximum to Holocene post-extinction, on which to scaffold ecological inferences; (2) quantify changes in mesocarnivore community structure and ecomorphology; and (3) weigh the relative importance of climate versus extinctions in shifting mesocarnivore feeding ecology. By integrating paleontology and community ecology, this research will obtain deep historical insight into modern ecosystem function. Additionally, this project enables the Fellow to: (1) refine skills in mentoring and managing a research team; (2) develop collections-management and curation experience through identifying and cataloging specimens; and (3) strengthen outreach by innovating strategies for collections-based citizen science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: La Brea Tar Pits and Museum

por.por_cntn:
The last Ice Age in North America (late Pleistocene; ending approximately 12,000 years ago) is well known for its charismatic megafauna: large animals like the saber-tooth cat, dire wolf, giant ground sloth, and mammoth that are now extinct but live on through popular culture. Less known is that this megafaunal community used to coexist with smaller animals—animals that share our spaces today. Coyotes that chase pets, raccoons that dig through trash, skunks that interrupt evening walks—all of these small to medium-sized urban carnivores have histories deeper in time than their current dominance in today’s cities might suggest. Understanding these histories may illuminate the resilience of this modern carnivore community: their responses to large-scale ecological and environmental change in the past may inform their response to continuing anthropogenic change into the future.

While the fossil history of mammals in North America is dominated by large carnivores and prey, most mammalian carnivores today are small (“mesocarnivores”): a taxonomic transition that followed a combination of climatic change, megafaunal extinctions, and human disturbance at the end of the last Ice Age. Here, I evaluate response to these intersecting major impacts in a mesocarnivore community spanning the last 55,000 years: the fossil record at the Rancho La Brea (RLB) asphalt seeps (popularly the La Brea Tar Pits) in Los Angeles, California, USA. Though the megafauna from this site have had over a century of intensive study, the mesocarnivores have received comparatively little attention. In this project, I use radiocarbon-dating to generate the first chronology of Rancho La Brea mesocarnivores, apply stable isotope analysis of carbon and nitrogen to track resource use, and lead a team of four undergraduate interns to collect data on ecological function based on skeletal size and shape. For context, I refer to historic specimens in the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, which has been collecting in southern California for over the last century.

Excluding coyotes—the only well-studied RLB mesocarnivore—the RLB asphalt seeps preserve five mesocarnivore species each represented by at least 10 individuals: American badger (Taxidea taxus), bobcat (Lynx rufus), grey fox (Urocyon cinereoargenteus), striped skunk (Mephitis mephitis), and long-tailed weasel (Mustela frenata). While these five species continue to live in the area today—becoming integral parts of southern California’s urban ecosystems—44 mesocarnivore radiocarbon dates indicate that not all species inhabited RLB at the same time. Rather, almost all fossil specimens of bobcats, grey foxes, and striped skunks date to between 30,000 and 40,000 years ago—before the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM)—with the earliest badgers appearing only around 12,000 years ago. No sampled mesocarnivore specimens date to the LGM itself, possibly because mesocarnivores were sparse in the area at that time, or possibly because the low temperatures at the LGM decreased the asphalt’s potential for entrapment.

In multiple ecologically relevant measurements of the skeleton, RLB specimens differ significantly from historic (<100 years old) representatives of the same species from the same geographic area. Fossil mesocarnivores were generally larger, decreasing in body size toward the present by as much as 27%. They also tended to exhibit a greater degree of adaptation for carnivory, such as longer slicing blades on molars and generally more robust teeth. These traits would have been advantageous in fending off competition from now-extinct megafaunal predators as well as taking advantage of now-extinct megafaunal prey. Each species also shows unique differences between fossil and modern specimens in the size and shape of limb bones; some especially complex differences necessitate three-dimensional analyses (rather than simply linear measurements) that are outside the scope of the current grant. These differences highlight shifts in locomotor ability, potentially recording responses to environmental change.

Further, the mesocarnivore stable-isotope landscape show differences that may record species-specific changes in diet but also may reflect shifts in the environment. All species except the weasel demonstrate higher-on-average and more variable δ13C toward the modern-day than pre-LGM; the striped skunk & grey fox also exhibit lower-on-average δ15N in the Holocene to modern than pre-LGM. Interpretation of these results is complicated by how δ13C may record which plant types an animal ate but also a shift in the available plants, and by how δ15N may correlate with the proportion of meat in an animal’s diet but also with the level of aridity in an area. Ongoing ecosystem-level work by colleagues at RLB should clarify these competing hypotheses in the future.

Leveraging biogeochemical and ecomorphological techniques, this study reveals the roots of today’s urban ecosystems in the last Ice Age and highlights their potential responses to anthropogenic change. While the grant is complete, the research directions that it has catalyzed are continuing. PI Balisi is now a curator at a natural history museum, working with students to expand on the questions first addressed in this grant, and leveraging paleobiology toward issues of modern global change.


Last Modified: 11/14/2023
Modified by: Mairin Balisi
